item.title: Nicole Elmer & Blair Dancy talks about TALA services in this video
item.dc:creator: bobbyjoseph
item.content:encoded:
[Blair Dancy] When you feel like you've contributed to the arts it goes beyond the economics it goes to the culture it's the soul of the city it's all the stuff that we live for, that we fight for it defines us.
[Nicole Elmer] My name is Nicole Elmer and I'm a filmmaker, I am just fascinated by what people create with medium such as painting, music, everything. It's just fascinating what humans can do. And I'm so inspired by it and I want to create and reach those heights myself and I think it's important and a social sense to have a dialogue and I think art causes that dialogue to start. So in the shadows my first feature, the idea was conceived in 2008 my co-producing partner Jorge Sermini and I went to a tiny island off the coast of Puerto Rico called Culebra and we did pick up scenes in 2011 and 2010, finished editing around 2012 So all of my free time for basically about five years was consumed by this film. The first time I realized we needed legal assistance was when we started talking with a different distribution company than the one we are currently with They gave us a huge list of deliverables that we had to fill out in addition to the contract of course and looking it over we were just overwhelmed I actually have a very vivid memory of sitting on a couch with Jorge would breathe deeply, read one paragraph and stop and let it sink into our heads. We just didn’t understand some of the terminology. There were just run on sentences that didn't seem to ever stop, my brain just felt so it was gonna explode. I did not become a filmmaker, to spend 50% of my time trying to understand the legal side. We put so much money and so much time into this project that we really felt that we needed a guide so that's why I contacted TALA.
[Blair Dancy] We are Texas accountants and lawyers for the Arts and we provide legal and accounting services education to the greater Texas artistic community, that includes individuals as well as nonprofits we do seminars, provide the educational component for various issues and then we also fulfil service requests for financially qualifying artists and arts nonprofits so that they can then get their various specific issues taken care of
[Nicole Elmer] They paired us up with somebody, who was just immediately responsive, didn't talk down to us, didn't make us feel like we were stupid for things we didn't understand I felt like we just came out with a better understanding of the whole process.
[Blair Dancy] TALA has helped not only Nicole but hundreds of other artists annually, thousands over the years people who need help all the way from El Paso, to Longview to Amarillo down to the valley it's it's really every corner of the state help them through very specific complicated deals, help them understand what it is that they're dealing with and through that we help the artist community as a whole empower themselves and in turn that helps the whole state.
[Nicole Elmer] I will definitely use TALA again. It was invaluable it freed up time for me to really do what I have to do as a director which is finish the movie.
[Blair Dancy] I find there's a lot of satisfaction on my end and I see that in others the people who come out and volunteer. I see that they they feel like they're part of something much bigger than themselves and that's what's really rewarding about this it's it's enabling the artists to do more for themselves and for the art work ultimately and it lets them know that there are people out there looking out for them people who care, people who want to help and people who want to see them succeed.
[Nicole Elmer] It says a lot about what these lawyers feel about the importance of art in our society, the fact that they're willing to work with filmmakers like me that work with very small budgets over prolonged periods of time they're willing to work with individuals like me that create these these works that don't have the funding for legal advice and they do it because they care about art, they care about film they care about in many ways the success of the artists creating this material.
[Blair Dancy] We have a vibrant culture here in Texas. It's so much more than having just offices and residences and businesses in a town yet you need more and that's where this comes in. It's the artwork, it's the paintings, it's the music at the bar, it's the writing to get someone who's gonna do a creative writing piece for the local paper it's all of these things, and when it all comes together it's really what defines us isn't it?
(music)
TALA attorney volunteers assist over 350 income eligible artist each year.
Their legal and accounting matters might otherwise remain unresolved and unrepresented.
750 artists are helped each year through TALA's educational programming and clinics.
These services enhance artists' careers and economic viability.
Find out if you qualify. TALA - Texas Accountants and Lawyers for the arts. talarts.org
Executive Produce: Goodwill Industries of Central Texas
Producers: Kali' and Dan Rourke Christina Martel Holly Wood Jane Wu Toni Thomasson Becky and Mark Thomasson Peggy Ellithorpe Sherri Patten Christine St.Clair Cliff Wildman Alissa and Ron McCain Peter Bramley Shelley Moore Daniel Malyszka-Prele Charisse Hughen Elliott Sadler Kenneth McKenzie
Directors and Editors Luis Esteban Caffesse Clifford Wildman
PitchProductions.com
Special Thanks Nicole Elmer Jorge Sermini
"In The Shadow" www.IntheShadowMovie.com

item.title: Tax Help
item.dc:creator: herinnisha
item.content:encoded:
Tax Help

TALA does not offer Individual 1040 and Non-Profit 990 Tax Filing Services. Those needing assistance filing a 1040 should contact one of the following tax service organizations, just click on the city name below to get more info: Austin (External Link) Beaumont (External Link) Corpus Christi (External Link) Dallas (External Link) El Paso (External Link) Houston (External Link) Lubbock (External Link) Midland (External Link) Odessa (External Link) San Antonio (External Link) The IRS offers free in-person federal tax filing too, but with restrictions. You must have an adjusted gross income below $51,000 to qualify. The tax preparation help is usually provided in IRS offices, libraries and colleges around the country. You can find a free tax help in the IRS Location Finder here (External Link). IT IS YOUR RESPONSIBILITY TO CONFIRM YOUR ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE SERVICES BEFOREHAND. EACH OF THESE SERVICES RESERVES THE RIGHT TO REFUSE SERVICE TO ANYONE FOR ANY REASON.

item.title: Welcome to TALA
item.dc:creator: christosptr
item.content:encoded:
Mission Statement

Texas Accountants and Lawyers for the Arts (TALA) provides Texas artists and arts organizations with legal and accounting assistance to enable them to maximize their potential, shape our cultural landscape, and contribute to the creative economy. TALA provides individualized volunteer legal and accounting services to financially qualified artists and arts nonprofits, hosts educational seminars and clinics, and produces educational materials to increase business knowledge in the arts. Read more on TALA Mission...

Do I Qualify for TALA Assistance?

To qualify for TALA assistance, you must be:
  • A resident of the state of Texas or organization established in the state of Texas, AND
  • (An individual artist with a combined annual household income less than $50,000 OR
  • an arts nonprofit organization with annual gross revenue less than $200,000 AND less than $500,000 in assets)
Read more on TALA Assistance...

Nicole Elmer & Blair Dancy talks about TALA services on this video

Note: This video is captioned [avl_video id="1031" url="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FprQKc0bCKY" poster="/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/TALA_Video_Poster.jpg"] Texas Accountants and Lawyers for the Arts proudly acknowledges the following patrons for their generous sponsorship of the programs and clinics that support our mission to serve the Texas creative economy

This website is a public resource for information about our organization and is not intended to provide legal advice.

item.title: Board and Staff
item.dc:creator: bobbyjoseph
item.content:encoded:
Texas Accountants and Lawyers for the Arts (TALA) was formed in 1979 to help meet the legal and accounting needs of artists and arts nonprofits across the State of Texas. TALA volunteers throughout the state handle more than 350 matters per year. This amounts to more than six hundred thousand dollars annually in donated services to the arts and cultural community.TALA’s pro bono legal and accounting services are offered to artists from all creative disciplines, including visual artists, musicians, actors, dancers, film makers and writers. Over 600 attorneys and accountants volunteer their time each year, assisting in legal and accounting matters that might otherwise remain unresolved and unrepresented.TALA’s services include legal and accounting assistance, nonprofit incorporation, dispute resolution services, and educational programs and publications for artists and arts nonprofits to help apply legal and accounting concepts for their benefit. Membership and Donor dollars provide for TALA's small staff, office facilities and the insurance coverage necessary to coordinate and support TALA volunteers.

Board of Directors Executive Committee

  • Elizabeth Rogers, President (Greenberg Traurig, LLP)
  • Brooks Rice, Vice President of External Affairs (Brooks Rice Law)
  • Jamie Schue, Secretary President-Elect (ERCOT)

Board Members

  • Jamie Baker (Thompson Coe)
  • Megan Dagerman (Norton Rose Fulbright)
  • Rahul D. Engineer (Intel)
  • Peter Helf (Austin Chamber Music Center)
  • Erik Metzger (Intel)
  • Andrea Perez Affleck (Kessler Collins PC)
  • Lisa Sretenovic (The Mangold Group Certified Public Accountants, PC)

Staff

  • Angela Lee, Legal Director
  • Alissa McCain, Executive Director

item.title: What we do?
item.dc:creator: herinnisha
item.content:encoded:
• Lawyer and Accountant Referral
  • Legal Services for Artists and Arts Nonprofits
  • Accounting Services for Artists and Arts Nonprofits
  • Cases Not Handled

Lawyer and Accountant Referral

TALA matches low-income artists and small budget arts nonprofits with volunteer attorneys and accountants to assist with arts-related legal and financial matters.

Move to top

Legal Services for Artists and Arts Nonprofits

  • Non-Profit Arts Organization Incorporation
  • Contract Drafting, Negotiation and Review
  • Estate Planning for Artists
  • Copyright
  • Trademark
  • IP Licensing
  • Arts-Related Landlord/Tenant Issues
  • Demand Letters
  • Dispute Resolution / Arts Mediation

Move to top

Accounting Services for Artists and Arts Nonprofits

  • Financial Reviews
  • Chart of Accounts
  • Financial Statements
  • Annual Budgets
  • Application for tax exempt status
  • Employment Taxes

Move to top

Please be advised that TALA is not staffed to provide emergency legal or accounting assistance, nor does TALA provide representation to individuals or organizations before courts, arbitration panels, administrative proceedings, or other governmental bodies.

Cases Not Handled Through TALA

  • Family Law (Child Custody, Divorce, etc)
  • Criminal Law
  • Personal Injury
  • Litigation
  • 1040 Individual Tax Return
  • Audits

Move to top

item.title: Membership
item.dc:creator: herinnisha
item.content:encoded:
Ready to become a member of TALA?

Individual Artists Arts and Non Profit Organization Application Forms for Non Profit Organization Members Application Forms for Individual Artists Current Members

Individual Artists

Are you an individual artist making less than $50,000 a year combined gross income?

The annual membership fee for Individual Artists is $75, which entitles you to receive services from TALA for an entire year.

Move to top

Arts Non Profit Organization

Are you an arts nonprofit with annual gross revenue less than $200,000 and less than $500,000 in total assets?

The annual membership fee for Nonprofit Organizations is $250, which entitles you to receive services from TALA for an entire year.

Move to top

Application Forms for Individual Artists

New Member

If you have never had a TALA membership, or if your membership with TALA lapsed over 18 months ago, please use the New Individual Artist Application

Renewing Member

You will need to know your Individual Artist Member ID Number in order to renew.Please use the Renewing Member Application.

Move to top

Application Forms for Non Profit Organization Members

New Member

If you have never had a TALA nonprofit organization membership, or if that membership with TALA lapsed over 18 months ago, please use the NEW Nonprofit Membership Application

Renewing Member

You will need to know your Non Profit Membership ID Number in order to renew.Please use the Renewing Nonprofit Member Application.

Move to top

Current Members

Do you need to make a request for assistance? Use one of these forms to let us know about your issue.
  • Individual Request for Assistance Form
  • NonProfit Organization Request for Assistance Form
If you are having issues with our new membership system online, please email attorney@talarts.org for assistance. If you are emailing on a holiday or a weekend, please understand we may be checking emails M-F only, on non-holidays, during regular business hours. Please be patient and we will help you.

Move to top

item.title: Volunteer
item.dc:creator: herinnisha
item.content:encoded:
What is TALA?

Texas Accountants and Lawyers for the Arts is a 501 (c)(3) nonprofit organization that provides pro bono legal and accounting services to individual artists and nonprofit organizations statewide. TALA has been serving Texas artists since 1979. TALA handles some cases in-house, but the majority of cases are handled by TALA Volunteer Attorneys and Accountants from across the state.

Who does TALA serve?

TALA assists individual artists who are members of TALA and whose annual household income is $50,000 or less. Our clients come from many artistic disciplines including the visual arts, writing, acting, dancing, singing, musical performance, and performance art. Nonprofit clients include museums, theater companies, arts groups, dance troupes, libraries and writers’ guilds. Nonprofits must have annual revenues less than $200,000 and total assets less than $500,000 to qualify.

How does TALA membership work?

In order to receive TALA services, artists and nonprofits must become members. Individual memberships for artists are $50, bands are $100, and nonprofit organizations are $200. The membership fee helps defray administrative costs. With a one year membership, members receive unlimited (within the available scope of the services we provide) pro bono legal and accounting services, a subscription to the TALA newsletter and Art Law and Accounting Reporter, and invitations to TALA events.

Who can become a volunteer?

To handle TALA cases, volunteer attorneys must be licensed in the state of Texas and be in good standing with the Bar. An accounting volunteer must be a licensed CPA. Anyone can volunteer for special events and assist in the TALA office. Due to legal relationships between TALA and its clients, TALA does not use legal or accounting volunteers for administrative tasks within the office.

What types of legal cases does TALA handle?

All legal cases TALA handles must be art related. For artists, that includes copyright, gallery agreements, contracts, trademark, civil rights, entertainment issues, general business advice, bankruptcy, wills, forming a corporation, insurance, and landlord/tenant studio disputes. For nonprofits TALA handles cases dealing with resolving board disputes, board liability, dissolving nonprofit organizations, employment, creating nonprofit organizations, and tax issues. TALA can also handle some mediation cases for artists and nonprofits.

What types of accounting cases does TALA handle?

Accounting volunteers provide TALA clients with a wide variety of services. For the arts organizations, setting up their bookkeeping, payroll, and accounting related questions are the most common cases. For individual artists, accountants can assist with bookkeeping and setting up record keeping systems.

What is the volunteer process?

Every 2 to 3 weeks, an email is sent to all TALA volunteers listing the available cases. Once you run a conflicts check, volunteers should email TALA informing us of which cases you are interested in taking. A letter is then sent to both the client and the volunteer that confirms the case has been taken and also informs both parties of how to contact each other. It is the client’s responsibility to make initial contact with the volunteer, but the volunteer may make the initial contact if they choose to do so.

What is the time commitment?

The time commitment varies for each case, but generally, TALA cases are fairly brief in nature. TALA does not provide ongoing representation with the same attorney or accountant, so once you complete the matter, you are released. Although preparation of Form 990 is not time intensive, it can lend itself to an annual assignment.

Cases not handled by TALA:

  • Family Law
  • Criminal Law
  • Personal Injury
  • Litigation*
  • Audits

* TALA does consult on small claims issues

How is the case closed?

When representation is complete, please fill out a Volunteer Evaluation Form and return it to TALA. This allows TALA to keep accurate records and lets us know what we can do to better serve you as a volunteer.

Volunteer Your Time

TALA is seeking licensed legal and accounting professionals as well as individuals who would like to consider volunteering their time and expertise in the following areas:
  • Legal Services (Must be a Texas licensed attorney)
  • Accounting Services (Must be a Texas-licensed CPA)
  • Legal or Accounting Speaker for TALA seminars and workshops
  • Legal or Accounting Writer for TALA publications
  • Dispute Resolution/Mediation
  • Graphic Design Services
  • Computer Services
  • Marketing
  • Office Assistance
If you are interested in volunteering:
  • Please fill out and submit our online Volunteer Interest Questionnaire
  • Current law and undergraduate students must apply to volunteer with TALA through our internship program
  • If you have other questions, please contact the TALA office. Please visit contact page for  Contact Details.

With a one year membership, members receive unlimited (within the available scope of the services we provide) pro bono legal and accounting services, a subscription to the TALA newsletter and Art Law and Accounting Reporter, and invitations to TALA events.

Who can become a volunteer?

To handle TALA cases, volunteer attorneys must be licensed in the state of Texas and be in good standing with the Bar. An accounting volunteer must be a licensed CPA. Anyone can volunteer for special events and assist in the TALA office. Due to legal relationships between TALA and its clients, TALA does not use legal or accounting volunteers for administrative tasks within the office.

What types of legal cases does TALA handle?

All legal cases TALA handles must be art related. For artists, that includes copyright, gallery agreements, contracts, trademark, civil rights, entertainment issues, general business advice, bankruptcy, wills, forming a corporation, insurance, and landlord/tenant studio disputes. For nonprofits TALA handles cases dealing with resolving board disputes, board liability, dissolving nonprofit organizations, employment, creating nonprofit organizations, and tax issues. TALA can also handle some mediation cases for artists and nonprofits.

What types of accounting cases does TALA handle?

Accounting volunteers provide TALA clients with a wide variety of services. For the arts organizations, setting up their bookkeeping, payroll, and accounting related questions are the most common cases. For individual artists, accountants can assist with bookkeeping and setting up record keeping systems.

What is the volunteer process?

Every 2 to 3 weeks, an email is sent to all TALA volunteers listing the available cases. Once you run a conflicts check, volunteers should email TALA informing us of which cases you are interested in taking. A letter is then sent to both the client and the volunteer that confirms the case has been taken and also informs both parties of how to contact each other. It is the client’s responsibility to make initial contact with the volunteer, but the volunteer may make the initial contact if they choose to do so.

What is the time commitment?

The time commitment varies for each case, but generally, TALA cases are fairly brief in nature. TALA does not provide ongoing representation with the same attorney or accountant, so once you complete the matter, you are released. Although preparation of Form 990 is not time intensive, it can lend itself to an annual assignment.

Cases not handled by TALA :

  • Family Law
  • Criminal Law
  • Personal Injury
  • Litigation*
  • Audits

* TALA does consult on small claims issues

How is the case closed?

When representation is complete, please fill out a Volunteer Evaluation Form and return it to TALA . This allows TALA to keep accurate records and lets us know what we can do to better serve you as a volunteer.

Volunteer Your Time

TALA is seeking licensed legal and accounting professionals as well as individuals who would like to consider volunteering their time and expertise in the following areas:

  • Legal Services (Must be a Texas licensed attorney)
  • Accounting Services (Must be a Texas-licensed CPA)
  • Legal or Accounting Speaker for TALA seminars and workshops
  • Legal or Accounting Writer for TALA publications
  • Dispute Resolution/Mediation
  • Graphic Design Services
  • Computer Services
  • Marketing
  • Office Assistance
If you are interested in volunteering:
  • Please fill out and submit our online Volunteer Interest Questionnaire
  • Current law and undergraduate students must apply to volunteer with TALA through our internship program
  • If you have other questions, please contact the TALA office. Please visit contact page for  Contact Details.

Volunteer Your Time

TALA is seeking licensed legal and accounting professionals as well as individuals who would like to consider volunteering their time and expertise in the following areas:

  • Graphic Design Services
  • Computer Services
  • Marketing

  • Current law and undergraduate students must apply to volunteer with TALA through our internship program

item.title: Publications
item.dc:creator: herinnisha
item.content:encoded:
Disclosure Rules for Charitable Organizations

For organizations seeking information concerning the rules surrounding charitable contributions, Blazek & Vetterling has provided a comprehensive summary illustrating, among other things, how charitable contributions are recognized for tax purposes and how to assign fair market value to items offered for auction or as part of a gala fundraiser. A special thanks to CPA and TALA Board Member, Jody Blazek. (Published 2011)

Download Disclosure Rules- Word- 35KB

Fine Art Insurance Issues: A Selected Case Law Survey

Fine Art insurers are often faced with unique claim facts due to the nature of the asset at risk. When these facts give rise to coverage questions, the insurer may seek a legal coverage opinion prior to accepting or denying the claim. This article takes a survey of selected case law to assist insurers and their legal counsel identify and better understand certain Fine Art insurance issues upon which courts have provided guidance. The surveyed cases address entrustment, excluded risks, coverage amount and policy formation, fraud and forgery, and valuation and appraisal (with reference to the jurisdictions in which they were decided). Authored by Jamie K. Baker of Thompson, Coe, Cousins & Irons, L.L.P., Dallas, Texas and Darrell S. Cockcroft of Thompson, Coe, Cousins & Irons, L.L.P., Austin, Texas (Published Spring 2012)Download DALLAS Art Insurance Article - Word - 55KB

item.title: FAQs to be removed?
item.dc:creator: herinnisha
item.content:encoded:
FAQs

How can I get assistance from TALA ?

In order to receive assistance from TALA you must be a member. Once you are a member, we will look at the circumstances of your case and determine whether it can be handled by one of TALA's staff attorneys or pro bono volunteers. If we cannot assist you, we will do our best to refer you to an attorney who may be able to help.

Are there any reasons TALA may not be able to assist me?

While TALA does its best to help as many clients as possible, TALA reserves the right to reject a client's application for assistance under certain circumstances, including, but not limited to: Matters requiring litigation. TALA does not handle litigation. TALA does, however, provide mediation services, which is a possible alternative to litigation. Complex matters potentially requiring too much time to be resolved on a volunteer basis. Unavailability of a qualified volunteer to handle a particular request. You may not meet our income guidelines. Please also note that TALA cannot accept cases that require immediate assistance. If you need immediate assistance, we'll do our best to find you an appropriate referral agency.

What kind of cases does TALA handle?

TALA assists with legal issues pertaining to individual artists: contracts, copyright, licensing agreements, art-related insurance, landlord/tenant issues (pertaining to studio space). TALA does not assist business entities such as record labels or production companies. TALA also assists with legal issues for arts nonprofits: board issues, contracts, leasing agreements, etc. TALA does not handle: tax returns, family law, criminal law, business associations, bankruptcy, or litigation.

Where can I look for help if my issue is not something handled by TALA?

For general legal assistance throughout Texas: www.texaslawhelp.org For nonprofit organizations in Texas: http://www.tano.org/ For a referral for an attorney for hire, contact the State Bar of Texas Lawyer Referral Service, or for Austin and Central Texas, contact the Lawyer Referral Service of Central Texas. For a referral for a CPA for hire, contact the Texas Society for CPAs. If you aren’t sure if TALA handles your type of case, just drop us a line at info@talarts.org. We’ll do our best to help!

item.title: Do I Qualify?
item.dc:creator: herinnisha
item.content:encoded:
Eligibility Criteria

To be matched with a volunteer through TALA, you must be:
  • A resident of the state of Texas or organization established in the state of Texas, AND
  • An individual artist with a combined annual household income less than $50,000 OR an arts nonprofit organization with annual gross revenue less than $200,000 AND less than $500,000 in assets.

If you meet the qualifications above, you are financially eligible to become a member of TALA and receive pro bono assistance with legal and accounting matters. First, become a member of TALA.Then, fill out a Request for Assistance Form:

  • All Individual Artist Members please use the Individual Request for Assistance.
  • All NonProfit Organizations please use the Organization Request for Assistance.

All individuals and organizations requesting assistance must be current members of TALA. Renew or join TALA as a member.

item.title: Donate
item.dc:creator: bobbyjoseph
item.content:encoded:
TALA's services are made possible through generous donations. Your contribution will directly impact Texas artists.
Contribution Levels
Level Amount Impact
 FRIEND  $100 pays to match one artist in need with a volunteer lawyer or accountant
 SPONSOR  $500 creates an arts related 501c3 corporation, including TALA staff time filing forms with the state and drafting bylaws, activities statements, conflict of interest policies, and three-year budgets. A volunteer lawyer completes the final paperwork
 PATRON  $1,000 sponsors an educational seminar on a specific accounting or legal topic
BENEFACTOR  $2,500 underwrites a clinic staffed by volunteer professionals, typically serving 15-25 artists
ANGEL $5,000 allows TALA to engage a contractor in another city for a year, exponentially increasing programming and outreach
[seamless-donations]

item.title: Becoming A Volunteer
item.dc:creator: herinnisha
item.content:encoded:
Test

  • Toggle High Contrast
  • Toggle Grayscale
  • Toggle Font size

What is TALA?

Texas Accountants and Lawyers for the Arts is a 501 (c)(3) nonprofit organization that provides pro bono legal and accounting services to individual artists and nonprofit organizations statewide. TALA has been serving Texas artists since 1979. TALA handles some cases in-house, but the majority of cases are handled by TALA Volunteer Attorneys and Accountants from across the state.

Who does TALA serve?

TALA assists individual artists who are members of TALA and whose annual household income is $50,000 or less. Our clients come from many artistic disciplines including the visual arts, writing, acting, dancing, singing, musical performance, and performance art. Nonprofit clients include museums, theater companies, arts groups, dance troupes, libraries and writers’ guilds. Nonprofits must have annual revenues less than $200,000 and total assets less than $500,000 to qualify.

How does TALA membership work?

In order to receive TALA services, artists and nonprofits must become members. Individual memberships for artists are $50, bands are $100, and nonprofit organizations are $200. The membership fee helps defray administrative costs. With a one year membership, members receive unlimited (within the available scope of the services we provide) pro bono legal and accounting services, a subscription to the TALA newsletter and Art Law and Accounting Reporter, and invitations to TALA events.

Who can become a volunteer?

To handle TALA cases, volunteer attorneys must be licensed in the state of Texas and be in good standing with the Bar. An accounting volunteer must be a licensed CPA. Anyone can volunteer for special events and assist in the TALA office. Due to legal relationships between TALA and its clients, TALA does not use legal or accounting volunteers for administrative tasks within the office.

What types of legal cases does TALA handle?

All legal cases TALA handles must be art related. For artists, that includes copyright, gallery agreements, contracts, trademark, civil rights, entertainment issues, general business advice, bankruptcy, wills, forming a corporation, insurance, and landlord/tenant studio disputes. For nonprofits TALA handles cases dealing with resolving board disputes, board liability, dissolving nonprofit organizations, employment, creating nonprofit organizations, and tax issues. TALA can also handle some mediation cases for artists and nonprofits.

What types of accounting cases does TALA handle?

Accounting volunteers provide TALA clients with a wide variety of services. For the arts organizations, setting up their bookkeeping, payroll, and accounting related questions are the most common cases. For individual artists, accountants can assist with bookkeeping and setting up record keeping systems.

What is the volunteer process?

Every 2 to 3 weeks, an email is sent to all TALA volunteers listing the available cases. Once you run a conflicts check, volunteers should email TALA informing us of which cases you are interested in taking. A letter is then sent to both the client and the volunteer that confirms the case has been taken and also informs both parties of how to contact each other. It is the client’s responsibility to make initial contact with the volunteer, but the volunteer may make the initial contact if they choose to do so.

What is the time commitment?

The time commitment varies for each case, but generally, TALA cases are fairly brief in nature. TALA does not provide ongoing representation with the same attorney or accoutant, so once you complete the matter, you are released. Although preparation of Form 990 is not time intensive, it can lend itself to an annual assignment.

Cases not handled by TALA:

  • Family Law
  • Criminal Law
  • Personal Injury
  • Litigation*
  • Audits
* TALA does consult on small claims issues

How is the case closed?

When representation is complete, please fill out a Volunteer Evaluation Form and return it to TALA. This allows TALA to keep accurate records and lets us know what we can do to better serve you as a volunteer.

If you are interested in becoming a TALA volunteer:

  • Contact Legal Director Angela L. Lee at 800.526.8252 or attorney@talarts.org OR
  • Fill out the online Volunteer Interest Questionnaire

TALA can also handle some mediation cases for artists and nonprofits.

What types of accounting cases does TALA handle?

Accounting volunteers provide TALA clients with a wide variety of services. For the arts organizations, setting up their bookkeeping, payroll, and accounting related questions are the most common cases. For individual artists, accountants can assist with bookkeeping and setting up record keeping systems.";s:5:"autop";b:1;s:12:"_sow_form_id";s:13:"56298aca7fa5c";s:11:"panels_info";a:6:{s:5:"class";s:31:"SiteOrigin_Widget_Editor_Widget";s:3:"raw";b:0;s:4:"grid";i:0;s:4:"cell";i:0;s:2:"id";i:5;s:5:"style";a:1:{s:18:"background_display";s:4:"tile";}}}i:6;a:5:{s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:4:"text";s:557:"

What is the volunteer process?

Every 2 to 3 weeks, an email is sent to all TALA volunteers listing the available cases. Once you run a conflicts check, volunteers should email TALA informing us of which cases you are interested in taking. A letter is then sent to both the client and the volunteer that confirms the case has been taken and also informs both parties of how to contact each other. It is the client’s responsibility to make initial contact with the volunteer, but the volunteer may make the initial contact if they choose to do so. What is the time commitment?

The time commitment varies for each case, but generally, TALA cases are fairly brief in nature. TALA does not provide ongoing representation with the same attorney or accoutant, so once you complete the matter, you are released. Although preparation of Form 990 is not time intensive, it can lend itself to an annual assignment.

Cases not handled by TALA:

  • Family Law
  • Criminal Law
  • Personal Injury
  • Litigation*
  • Audits
* TALA does consult on small claims issues

What is TALA?

Texas Accountants and Lawyers for the Arts is a 501 (c)(3) nonprofit organization that provides pro bono legal and accounting services to individual artists and nonprofit organizations statewide. TALA has been serving Texas artists since 1979. TALA handles some cases in-house, but the majority of cases are handled by TALA Volunteer Attorneys and Accountants from across the state.

";s:5:"autop";b:1;s:12:"_sow_form_id";s:13:"56298a17d64c3";s:11:"panels_info";a:6:{s:5:"class";s:31:"SiteOrigin_Widget_Editor_Widget";s:3:"raw";b:0;s:4:"grid";i:0;s:4:"cell";i:0;s:2:"id";i:0;s:5:"style";a:1:{s:18:"background_display";s:4:"tile";}}}i:1;a:5:{s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:4:"text";s:516:"

Who does TALA serve?

TALA assists individual artists who are members of TALA and whose annual household income is $50,000 or less. Our clients come from many artistic disciplines including the visual arts, writing, acting, dancing, singing, musical performance, and performance art. Nonprofit clients include museums, theater companies, arts groups, dance troupes, libraries and writers’ guilds. Nonprofits must have annual revenues less than $200,000 and total assets less than $500,000 to qualify.

How does TALA membership work?

In order to receive TALA services, artists and nonprofits must become members. Individual memberships for artists are $50, bands are $100, and nonprofit organizations are $200. The membership fee helps defray administrative costs. With a one year membership, members receive unlimited (within the available scope of the services we provide) pro bono legal and accounting services, a subscription to the TALA newsletter and Art Law and Accounting Reporter, and invitations to TALA events.

item.title: Support
item.dc:creator: herinnisha
item.content:encoded: [child-pages depth="1"]

item.title: FAQs
item.dc:creator: alimustan
item.content:encoded:
How can I get assistance from TALA?

In order to receive assistance from TALA you must be a member. Once you are a member, we will look at the circumstances of your case and determine whether it can be handled by one of TALA's staff attorneys or pro bono volunteers. If we cannot assist you, we will do our best to refer you to an attorney who may be able to help.

Are there any reasons TALA may not be able to assist me?

While TALA does its best to help as many clients as possible, TALA reserves the right to reject a client's application for assistance under certain circumstances, including, but not limited to:Matters requiring litigation. TALA does not handle litigation. TALA does, however, provide mediation services, which is a possible alternative to litigation.Complex matters potentially requiring too much time to be resolved on a volunteer basis.Unavailability of a qualified volunteer to handle a particular request.You may not meet our income guidelines.While TALA does its best to help as many clients as possible, TALA reserves the right to reject a client's application for assistance under certain circumstances, including, but not limited to:
  • Matters requiring litigation. TALA does not handle litigation. TALA does, however, provide mediation services, which is a possible alternative to litigation.
  • Complex matters potentially requiring too much time to be resolved on a volunteer basis.
  • Unavailability of a qualified volunteer to handle a particular request.
  • You may not meet our income guidelines.
Please also note that TALA cannot accept cases that require immediate assistance. If you need immediate assistance, we'll do our best to find you an appropriate referral agency.

What kind of cases does TALA handle?

  • TALA assists with legal issues pertaining to individual artists: contracts, copyright, licensing agreements, art-related insurance, landlord/tenant issues (pertaining to studio space).
  • TALA does not assist business entities such as record labels or production companies.
  • TALA also assists with legal issues for arts nonprofits: board issues, contracts, leasing agreements, etc.
  • TALA does not handle: tax returns, family law, criminal law, business associations, bankruptcy, or litigation.

Where can I look for help if my issue is not something handled by TALA?

  • For general legal assistance throughout Texas: www.texaslawhelp.org
  • For nonprofit organizations in Texas: http://www.tano.org/
  • For a referral for an attorney for hire, contact the State Bar of Texas Lawyer Referral Service, or for Austin and Central Texas, contact the Lawyer Referral Service of Central Texas.
  • For a referral for a CPA for hire, contact the Texas Society for CPAs.
  • If you aren’t sure if TALA handles your type of case, just drop us a line at We’ll do our best to help!

item.title: Accessibility
item.dc:creator: bobbyjoseph
item.content:encoded:
This page has instruction on how to use the TALA web site when navigating with keyboard or using other assistive technology. Note: For the best accessibility experience use Firefox

Keyboard Navigation

To navigate the menu use the arrow keys. You can navigate only the top menus using the tab. This will skip the sub menus. When in a menu that has sub-menu press the down arrow to open a sub-menu. When in a sub-menu press the Esc, left or right arrow to move to the top level menu and then continue using the arrow keys. If press the tab key then the focus will move to the next focusable element. When navigating menu with the up and down arrows with Firefox the screen will also move. This is a know Firefox limitation. To stop the screen from moving use the Alt+Up and Alt+Down keys.

 Navigation Keys for the main menu

Navigation Keys for main menu
Action Key
Navigate into/out of a Menu bar Tab or shift-tab
Navigate menu bar items Left and right arrow keys
Activate a menu bar item Spacebar or enter
Open a submenu Down arrow
Close a submenu Esc, or Left or right arrow keys

Navigation Keys for the FAQs page

The FAQs are using an accordion. To navigate the accordion use the arrow keys to navigate from one question to another. Then press the space or enter keys to activate the open the desired question.
Navigation Keys for the FAQs page
Action Key

item.title: Mission Statement
item.dc:creator: herinnisha
item.content:encoded:
Texas Accountants and Lawyers for the Arts (TALA) provides Texas artists and arts organizations with legal and accounting assistance to enable them to maximize their potential, shape our cultural landscape, and contribute to the creative economy.TALA provides individualized volunteer legal and accounting services to financially qualified artists and arts nonprofits, hosts educational seminars and clinics, and produces educational materials to increase business knowledge in the arts.

TALA was formed in 1979 to meet the legal and accounting needs of artists and arts nonprofits. Our services include lawyer and accountant pro bono assistance, dispute resolution services, and educational programs for the artistic and business community. Programs are designed to help artists apply legal and accounting concepts for their benefit.

Your membership dollars provide for TALA's small staff, office facilities, and the insurance coverage necessary to coordinate and support TALA volunteers. TALA does not represent individuals or organizations before courts, arbitration panels, administrative proceedings, or other governmental bodies. TALA is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization.

item.title: October: Estate Planning for Artists
item.dc:creator: herinnisha
item.content:encoded: If you're a TALA member, don't forget that your membership benefits include estate planning services. TALA members can be matched with an attorney to formalize arrangements by filling out the online Request for Assistance form. Learn about protecting yourself, your family, and your legacy with these essential estate planning documents: Last Will and Testament with a Contingent Trust Texas Durable Power of Attorney Texas Medical Power of Attorney Texas Directive to Physicians (Living Will) Appointment of Guardian for Minor or Special Needs Children Declaration of Guardian in the Event of Later Incapacity or Need of Guardian HIPAA Release Appointment of Agent to Control Disposition of Remains If you're not a TALA member and wish to be referred to an estate planning attorney, financially qualified artists may join TALA for $75 to receive services.  Your annual TALA membership allows you to request attorney services for matters related to creating and sustaining a career in the arts for one full calendar year.

item.title: TALA Dallas Week
item.dc:creator: herinnisha
item.content:encoded:
October 13-15, 2015 Dallas, Texas

TALA is coming to DFW to host three nights of education to advance your career in the arts! Events include: Legal Clinic for DFW Artists; Get Your Money workshop for claiming digital performance royalties; and Copyright for Artists seminar.

Registration Closed

item.title: October 7: Estate Planning for Austin Artists
item.dc:creator: herinnisha
item.content:encoded: Two out of every three Texans will die without a will. What is the cost to the family and the community when that happens? Learn about protecting yourself, your family and your legacy with these essential Estate Planning Documents: Last Will and Testament with a Contingent Trust Texas Durable Power of Attorney Texas Medical Power of Attorney Texas Directive to Physicians (Living Will) Appointment of Guardian for minor or special need Children Declaration of Guardian in the Event of Later Incapacity or Need of Guardian HIPAA Release Appointment of Agent to Control Disposition of Remains Wednesday, October 7 from 7:00 pm to 8:30 pm Austin Creative Alliance 81 San Marcos Street, Austin, Texas 78702 Click here to register.

item.title: The Austin Chapter of the Texas Society of CPAs Presents: Nonprofit Financial Class
item.dc:creator: herinnisha
item.content:encoded: As part of our ongoing desire to support the Austin nonprofit community, The Austin Chapter of the Texas Society of Certified Public Accountants is offering a free seminar for nonprofit staff and volunteers. This event is strictly a community service - there is nothing for sale, and no businesses will be promoted at the event. The seminar will focus on financial essentials for nonprofit organizations (NPOs): ‣ General Financial Governance for NPOs. Ever wonder what you’re getting into if you agree to serve on a non-profit board? Did you know that as a board member, you have a responsibility for the financial management of your nonprofit, even if you do not have a financial background? Do you wonder how to improve the financial practices at your organization when resources are limited? We will cover the fiduciary duties of a board member, the tax obligations of a not-for-profit organization, the essential insurance coverage nonprofits need, basics about budgeting, how to read financial statements, and key financial measurements. ‣ Internal Control and NPOs. Your nonprofit organization needs to protect its cash, investments, pledges, confidential information, property, equipment, reputation, clients, volunteers and staff at a time when fraud, identity theft, and information breaches are all too common. Good internal controls are the key to safeguarding your nonprofit organization. In our internal control class, we’ll go over the essentials of a good risk management plan – identifying the risks specific to your organization, creating a culture of integrity and implementing cost-effective internal controls. We have practical suggestions for controls, even for small nonprofit organizations. ‣ Form 990 and Other Tax Issues for NPOs. The tax return for non-profits can be challenging whether you’re preparing it in-house or just trying to understand what it all means. What does your Form 990 say about your organization? Many donors use the information to determine whether your organization is worth supporting. Learn why the IRS is asking certain questions on the 990 and how to comply with the rules for maintaining exempt status. We’ll also discuss some potentially taxable activities and what you can do to minimize the tax impact. Wednesday, October 7 from 8:00 am to 11:30 am Austin CPA Chapter Training Facility 3305 Northland Drive, Suite 402 Austin, Texas 78731 RSVPs are required:lmedrano@tscpa.net or (512) 445-0044 ext 117

item.title: Donate
item.dc:creator: bobbyjoseph
item.content:encoded:
TALA's services are made possible through generous donations. Your contribution will directly impact Texas artists.
Contribution Levels
Level Amount Impact
 FRIEND  $100 pays to match one artist in need with a volunteer lawyer or accountant
 SPONSOR  $500 creates an arts related 501c3 corporation, including TALA staff time filing forms with the state and drafting bylaws, activities statements, conflict of interest policies, and three-year budgets. A volunteer lawyer completes the final paperwork
 PATRON  $1,000 sponsors an educational seminar on a specific accounting or legal topic
BENEFACTOR  $2,500 underwrites a clinic staffed by volunteer professionals, typically serving 15-25 artists
ANGEL $5,000 allows TALA to engage a contractor in another city for a year, exponentially increasing programming and outreach

Donation Information

I would like to make a donation in the amount of:
